title: Reduce flushing
body:
This PR reduces log flushing in timely dataflow. In particular, it reduces use of `.clone()` which invariably results in `Logger::drop` being called, which flushes. Even when flushed, we attempt to re-allocate buffers less often, by intercepting empty buffers and using `Vec::new()` instead.

cc @umanwizard

title: small typo in chapter_2_5.md
body: the capability variable shows up in 2 code blocks -- in the first one it is `capability` and in the 2nd it's `_capability`. This PR changes the first occurrence to match the 2nd.

title: add '-ly' to time in documentation text
Change fn to fnmut
body:
This PR changes various occurrences of `Fn` to `FnMut` to allow more flexibility in operator closures. In particular, the allows closures to capture and re-use buffers, which they previously struggled to do.

cc @jamii

title: Re-order channel interactions
body:
This PR amends the order of pushing of elements into shared queues to avoid a race in which a thread is first alerted and then shown data. The details are not 100% clear to me at the moment, but we should try it out.

cc @ryzhyk

title: Allow logging multiple items
body: This PR adds the `log_many` method to loggers, which allows the user to provide an iterator over events. This has the potential to reduce the number of calls to `timer.elapsed()`, but it also allows derived streams to look "more transactional", with several logged events occurring at the same logical instant.

title: Improve `timely::execute` documentation.
body:
Clarify `timely::execute` behavior, namely (see #294):
- the method returns instantly
- dropping the value returned by the method will block until the timely
  computation terminates

title: [WIP] Export TcpBuilder construction
body:
This PR is the first steps in making a la carte construction of channel allocators from TCP connections easier. I expect this to be a bit of an iterative process where we learn about the next painful hunk of code that needs to be copy/paste'd and then split that open too.

cc @benesch

title: address underflow
body: `Duration` cannot be negative, and causes problems if that happens. So we guard that case and flatten down to a zero duration in that case.

title: README.md: Fix description mentioning `new_input`
body:
The README mentions that `new_input` is used for creating the input
stream but that hasn't been the case for a while. Adjust the text to
mention `input_from` which is what the code actually uses.

Bonus: Fix two more typos.

title: Delayed activations
body:
This PR is a first swing at allowing delayed activations, based on a `std::time::Duration`.

It is not yet tested, but the surrounding methods seem solid. Along with delayed activations, we now have a `replay_core` method that takes an option re-activation period; `Some(Duration::new(0, 0,))` is the standard behavior, any other duration drives a delayed reactivation, and `None` instructs the replayer not to re-activate itself (perhaps someone else will do so).

cc: @comnik, @benesch

title: Add interfaces for activating across thread boundaries
body:
Add interfaces that make it easy to send activations across thread
boundaries.

The approach is to give `Activations` an MPSC channel which it checks
for activation requests on every call to `advance`. Other threads can
acquire a handle to the send side of this object via `SyncActivations`
or `SyncActivator`, which are careful to also call unpark on the
associated worker thread for easy interop with `Worker.step_or_park`.

@frankmcsherry I created more interfaces than we actually need just to see how it feels–and I think it feels pretty good! My WIP @MaterializeInc branch only uses `SyncActivator`, so we could potentially inline the `SyncActivations` struct, but the symmetry with `Activator` and `Activations` seemed like it might be nice. We could also expose the underlying `SendError` directly, instead of replacing it with a `SyncActivationError`.

title: tidying up progress
body: This PR makes a few changes tidying up progress tracking, by improving the availability and methods for several of the core types. No functionality changes.

title: log operator shutdown
body: This PR explicitly shuts down operators in their drop code, to ensure that we produce logging events as this happens, instead of just incidentally dropping operators if a containing subgraph can determine that we have concluded.

title: Fixed typo
body:
Please verify the new semantics of the sentence are correct.
I assume they are from reading changelogs.

title: Builder simplification
body:
This PR simplifies the operator builder pattern to use fewer and simpler closures to define an operator. 

Previously, an operator was defined by two closures, "pull internal progress" and "push external progress" as these two methods were managed separately by subgraphs. They have since been unified into one method that does both (and maintains some invariants). The single method now takes a single argument which is their unified state (a mutable reference to the `SharedProgress` object that exchanges progress state between operator and scope, and whose contents define the contract between the two).

title: Support u/i128 types
body:
This commit can only be applied once abomination supports u/i128 types.

Signed-off-by: Moritz Hoffmann <antiguru@gmail.com>
